title: 104_hr1404
content: The policy of the United States aims to end animal suffering caused by steel jaw leghold traps by prohibiting their shipment in interstate or foreign commerce, along with fur articles from animals trapped in such traps. The Act defines terms related to fur articles, interstate or foreign commerce, import, and person. The Act defines terms related to fur articles, interstate or foreign commerce, import, and person. The term "person" includes individuals, partnerships, corporations, and government entities. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. A "steel jaw leghold trap" is a device designed to capture animals by snapping closed on their limb. The Act prohibits the import, export, or shipment of fur articles derived from animals trapped in steel jaw leghold traps. It is illegal to import fur in violation of this rule, transport leghold traps, or violate regulations set by the Secretary. Violators face fines up to $1,000 for the first offense and up to $5,000 and two years imprisonment for subsequent offenses. Rewards are also mentioned in the Act. SEC. 4. REWARDS. The Secretary pays half of the fine to anyone providing information leading to a conviction under this Act. Officers or employees of the government are not eligible for rewards. SEC. 5. ENFORCEMENT. The Secretary enforces the Act and regulations with the help of other agencies. Judges and magistrates can issue warrants for enforcement. Individuals can detain, search, seize, make arrests, and serve warrants for violations of the Act. The Secretary enforces the Act by seizing items and making arrests without a warrant for violations. Any seized item will be held pending criminal proceedings or forfeiture. Fur articles and steel jaw leghold traps are subject to specific regulations. The Secretary enforces the Act by seizing items and making arrests without a warrant for violations. Any seized item will be held pending criminal proceedings or forfeiture. Fur articles and steel jaw leghold traps are subject to specific regulations. Items seized in violation of the Act or regulations may be forfeited to the United States, and the Attorney General can seek injunctions against violators. The Secretary will create regulations to enforce the Act, and the Act will take effect one year after its enactment.
